items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Strong winds and unsettled weather may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast and on the Humber Estuary this morning, Saturday 01/10/2022. Areas most at risk include low lying coastal frontages, in particular around Kilnsea village. Flooding is possible between 07:45-10:00 on 01/10/2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 12:00 on 01/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: Strong winds and unsettled weather may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast and on the Humber Estuary this morning, Saturday 01/10/2022. Areas most at risk include low lying coastal frontages, in particular around Kilnsea village. Flooding is possible between 07:45-11:15 on 01/10/2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 12:00 on 01/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 13:30pm and 17:30pm today, Saturday 1st October. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.74mAODN at 15:30pm, on Saturday 1st October, which is 0.53m above tide tables, wind Force 6, westerly. mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 18:45pm on Saturday 1st October.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely between 13:30pm and 15:30pm today, Saturday 1st October. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. There is heightened risk from overtopping at Haddiscoe New Cut as the embankment level has been reduced. We have reduced our Flood Alert threshold and we are undertaking emergency repairs and planned future works to bring the embankment back up to condition. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 18:00pm today, Saturday 1st October.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels are remaining high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to yesterday's heavy rainfall. The lake level is forecast to remain above the Flood Alert threshold until midday Sunday 02/10/2022. 
Flooding could affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
River and lake levels are forecast to begin falling, but the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains. 
We are clearing debris from weed screens in the area and will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 02/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely between 13:30pm and 15:30pm today, Saturday 1st October. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. There is heightened risk from overtopping at Haddiscoe New Cut as the embankment level has been reduced. We have reduced our Flood Alert threshold and we are undertaking emergency repairs and planned future works to bring the embankment back up to condition. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 18:00pm today, Saturday 1st October.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Caister to Gorleston, including Great Yarmouth
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10:45am and 14:45pm today, Saturday 1st October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions. We expect high tide levels at Gorleston-on-Sea and water on towpaths and quaysides throughout Great Yarmouth. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Great Yarmouth of 1.95mAODN at 12:45pm, Saturday 1st October, which is 0.91m above tide tables, wind Force 5, westerly. mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 18:00pm today, Saturday 1st October.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15am and 15:15pm today, Saturday 1st October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions. We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.74mAODN at 13:15pm, Saturday 1st October, which is 0.68m above tide tables, wind Force 5, westerly. mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 18:00pm today, Saturday 1st October.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15am and 15:15pm today, Saturday 1st October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.74mAODN at 13:15pm, Saturday 1st October, which is 0.68m above tide tables, wind Force 5, westerly. mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 18:00pm today, Saturday 1st October.

items.description: Upper River Calder catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly and though levels in the Upper Calder have risen slightly this afternoon, they remain much lower than initially predicted. The heaviest rain has now passed so although there may be a further slight rise tonight with the remaining rainfall, we don't expect this to cause the river to rise to levels of concern. As levels are now below the flood risk threshold this flood alert is no longer in force.

There may be further rain overnight and through tomorrow, 1/10/22, however this will be localised and much lighter and is not expected to cause a significant rise in river levels. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths.

items.description: Upper Dove
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.    Further isolated rain showers are possible over the next 24 hours, but no impacts are forecast from these.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.

items.description: Isolated low lying properties along the tidal River Waveney
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is possible from 11:45am today, Saturday 1st October. Water levels are expected to continue to rise gradually over the next few hours. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. Areas most at risk are in St Olaves, Somerleyton, Burgh St Peter, Oulton Broad and Beccles. Roads likely to be affected include Beccles Road at St Olaves, Geldeston Lock Lane, Gillingham Dam and Fen Lane in Beccles. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9:00am tomorrow, Sunday 2nd October.
